message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Sex Differences in Mate Preferences Across 45 Countries: A Large-Scale Replication
Paper Abstract: Considerable research has examined human mate preferences across cultures, finding universal sex differences in preferences for attractiveness and resources as well as sources of systematic cultural variation. Two competing perspectives—an evolutionary psychological perspective and a biosocial role perspective—offer alternative explanations for these findings. However, the original data on which each perspective relies are decades old, and the literature is fraught with conflicting methods, analyses, results, and conclusions. Using a new 45-country sample ( N = 14,399), we attempted to replicate classic studies and test both the evolutionary and biosocial role perspectives. Support for universal sex differences in preferences remains robust: Men, more than women, prefer attractive, young mates, and women, more than men, prefer older mates with financial prospects. Cross-culturally, both sexes have mates closer to their own ages as gender equality increases. Beyond age of partner, neither pathogen prevalence nor gender equality robustly predicted sex differences or preferences across countries.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about biosocial theory and gender:

## Overview

Biosocial theory in motivational psychology identifies the differences between males and females concerning physical strength and reproductive capacity, and how these differences interact with expectations from society about social roles, producing the differences we see in gender.

## Key Perspective

When working with the feminist theory, Alice Eagly introduces the biosocial theory that considers the division of labor as a core principle.(no content)This theory emphasizes the social component of sex differences and operates around the idea of correspondence inference, which is the tendency to ascribe a person's behavior to their disposition orpersonality and to underestimate the extent to which situational factors elicited the behavior.

## Broader Context

The biosocial approach fits into a larger framework. Within the framework of the biopsychosocial model, gender is regarded by some as a complex and nuanced construct, shaped by the intricate interplay of social, psychological, and biological factors.

Biosocial theory represents a middle ground in the nature-versus-nurture debate about gender, arguing that biological differences interact with social and cultural forces to shape gender roles and behaviors, rather than being determined by either biology or society alone.

Web search results for query: "sex differences psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Sex differences in psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_differences_in_psychology"},{"title":"Sex differences in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_differences_in_humans"},{"title":"Category:Sex differences in psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Sex_differences_in_psychology"},{"title":"Sex–gender distinction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex–gender_distinction"},{"title":"Neuroscience of sex differences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuroscience_of_sex_differences"},{"title":"Sex differences in cognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_differences_in_cognition"},{"title":"Sex differences in intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_and_intelligence"},{"title":"Sexual strategies theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_strategies_theory"},{"title":"Human sexuality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_sexuality"},{"title":"Sex Differences in Cognitive Abilities - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_Differences_in_Cognitive_Abilities"}]

## Results for "sex differences psychology"

I found comprehensive information about sex differences in psychology. Here's an overview of the key findings:

### Definition and Scope

Sex differences in psychology are differences in the mental functions and behaviors of the sexes and are due to a complex interplay of biological, developmental, and cultural factors.(no content)Differences have been found in a variety of fields such as mental health, cognitive abilities, personality, emotion, sexuality, friendship, and tendency towards aggression.

### Nature vs. Nurture

A number of factors combine to influence the development of sex differences, including genetics and epigenetics; differences in brain structure and function; hormones, and socialization.(no content)Researchers and theorists take different perspectives on how much of gender is due to biological, neurochemical, and evolutionary factors (nature), or is the result of culture and socialization (nurture).

### Cognitive Differences

Research shows specific patterns in cognitive abilities: Female subjects tend to perform better on tests of verbal abilities and processing speed while males tend to perform better on tests of visual-spatial ability and crystallized intelligence. However, there are no significant sex differences in average IQ, though performance in certain cognitive tasks varies somewhat between sexes.

### Brain Research

Psychological sex differences are generally thought to reflect the interaction of genes, hormones, and social learning on brain development throughout the lifespan. However, a 2021 meta-synthesis found that sex accounted for less than 1% of the brain's structure or laterality.

Web search results for query: "evolutionary psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"Theoretical foundations of evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical_foundations_of_evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"Evolutionary psychology of language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology_of_language"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary psychology journals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_psychology_journals"},{"title":"Criticism of evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Criticism_of_evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"Evolutionary Psychology (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_Psychology_(journal)"},{"title":"History of evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"List of evolutionary psychologists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_evolutionary_psychologists"},{"title":"Evolutionary psychology of parenting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology_of_parenting"},{"title":"David Buss - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Buss"}]

## Evolutionary Psychology

Based on the search results, here's an overview of evolutionary psychology:

### Core Concept

Evolutionary psychology argues that much of human behavior is the output of psychological adaptations that evolved to solve recurrent problems in human ancestral environments.(no content)Its central assumption is that the human brain is composed of a large number of specialized mechanisms that were shaped by natural selection over a vast period of time to solve the recurrent information-processing problems faced by our ancestors.

### Theoretical Foundations

Evolutionary psychology primarily uses the theories of natural selection, sexual selection, and inclusive fitness to explain the evolution of psychological adaptations.(no content)Evolutionary psychologists say that natural selection has provided humans with many psychological adaptations, in much the same way that it generated humans' anatomical and physiological adaptations.

### Research Areas

Evolutionary psychologists hold that behaviors or traits that occur universally in all cultures are good candidates for evolutionary adaptations, including the abilities to infer others' emotions, discern kin from non-kin, identify and prefer healthier mates, and cooperate with others.(no content)The theories and findings of evolutionary psychology have applications in many fields, including economics, environment, health, law, management, psychiatry, politics, and literature.

### Criticism

Criticism of evolutionary psychology involves questions of testability, cognitive and evolutionary assumptions (such as modular functioning of the brain, and large uncertainty about the ancestral environment), importance of non-genetic and non-adaptive explanations, as well as political and ethical issues due to interpretations of research results.

### History

Jerome Barkow, Leda Cosmides and John Tooby popularized the term "evolutionary psychology" in their 1992 book The Adapted Mind: Evolutionary Psychology and The Generation of Culture.

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"Theoretical foundations of evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical_foundations_of_evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"Evolutionary psychology of language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology_of_language"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary psychology journals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_psychology_journals"},{"title":"Criticism of evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Criticism_of_evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"Evolutionary Psychology (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_Psychology_(journal)"},{"title":"History of evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"List of evolutionary psychologists - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_evolutionary_psychologists"},{"title":"Evolutionary psychology of parenting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology_of_parenting"},{"title":"David Buss - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Buss"}]

## Evolutionary Psychology

Based on the search results, here's an overview of evolutionary psychology:

### Core Concept

Evolutionary psychology argues that much of human behavior is the output of psychological adaptations that evolved to solve recurrent problems in human ancestral environments.(no content)Its central assumption is that the human brain is composed of a large number of specialized mechanisms that were shaped by natural selection over a vast period of time to solve the recurrent information-processing problems faced by our ancestors.

### Theoretical Foundations

Evolutionary psychology primarily uses the theories of natural selection, sexual selection, and inclusive fitness to explain the evolution of psychological adaptations.(no content)Evolutionary psychologists say that natural selection has provided humans with many psychological adaptations, in much the same way that it generated humans' anatomical and physiological adaptations.

### Research Areas

Evolutionary psychologists hold that behaviors or traits that occur universally in all cultures are good candidates for evolutionary adaptations, including the abilities to infer others' emotions, discern kin from non-kin, identify and prefer healthier mates, and cooperate with others.(no content)The theories and findings of evolutionary psychology have applications in many fields, including economics, environment, health, law, management, psychiatry, politics, and literature.

### Criticism

Criticism of evolutionary psychology involves questions of testability, cognitive and evolutionary assumptions (such as modular functioning of the brain, and large uncertainty about the ancestral environment), importance of non-genetic and non-adaptive explanations, as well as political and ethical issues due to interpretations of research results.

### History

Jerome Barkow, Leda Cosmides and John Tooby popularized the term "evolutionary psychology" in their 1992 book The Adapted Mind: Evolutionary Psychology and The Generation of Culture.

Web search results for query: "gender equality"

Links: [{"title":"Gender equality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_equality"},{"title":"Gender inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_inequality"},{"title":"Measures of gender equality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measures_of_gender_equality"},{"title":"Gender parity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_parity"},{"title":"Gender Equality Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_Equality_Index"},{"title":"Gender inequality in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_inequality_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Gender-equality paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender-equality_paradox"},{"title":"Gender Inequality Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_Inequality_Index"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Meetup/National Archives Gender Equality Edit-a-Thon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Meetup/National_Archives_Gender_Equality_Edit-a-Thon"},{"title":"European Institute for Gender Equality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Institute_for_Gender_Equality"}]

Here are the search results for "gender equality":

## Definition and Concepts

Gender equality can refer to equal opportunities or formal equality based on gender or refer to equal representation or equality of outcomes for gender, also called substantive equality.(no content)Gender equality is the goal, while gender neutrality and gender equity are practices and ways of thinking that help achieve the goal.

## Global Challenges

On a global scale, achieving gender equality requires eliminating harmful practices against women and girls, including sex trafficking, femicide, wartime sexual violence, gender wage gap, and other oppression tactics. Additionally, gender inequality is still ongoing today, with examples including women working longer hours than men, women suffering from education inequality throughout the world, being unable to express themselves freely, and being underpaid for performing the same work as men.

## Historical Progress

In wider society, the movement towards gender equality began with the suffrage movement in Western cultures in the late-19th century, which sought to allow women to vote and hold elected office.(no content)Since World War II, the women's liberation movement and feminism have created a general movement towards recognition of women's rights.

## Measurement Tools

There are over three hundred different indicators used to measure gender equality, as well as a number of prominent indices. The most prominent indices of gender equality include UNDP's Gender-related Development Index (GDI) and the Gender Empowerment Measure (GEM), introduced in 1995.(no content)More recent measures include the Gender Equity Index (GEI) introduced by Social Watch in 2004, the Global Gender Gap Index (GGGI) developed by the World Economic Forum in 2006, and the Social Institutions and Gender Index of OECD Development Centre from 2007.

Web search results for query: "mate preferences"

Links: [{"title":"Mating preferences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mating_preferences"},{"title":"Mate value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mate_value"},{"title":"Mate choice in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mate_choice_in_humans"},{"title":"Mate choice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mate_choice"},{"title":"Extended female sexuality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extended_female_sexuality"},{"title":"Mate choice copying - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mate_choice_copying"},{"title":"Human mating strategies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_mating_strategies"},{"title":"Ovulatory shift hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ovulatory_shift_hypothesis"},{"title":"Dating preferences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dating_preferences"},{"title":"Sexual selection in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_selection_in_humans"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about mate preferences:

## Overview

Mating preferences are qualities that one desires in a romantic or sexual partner.(no content)Research across many domains, such as evolutionary biology, psychology, and anthropology, shows that humans display both widely shared (consensual) preferences– like preferences for kindness, intelligence, and health– as well as sex-differentiated preferences shaped by ancestral selection pressures.

## Theoretical Framework

These preferences are understood within the framework of sexual selection (first proposed by Charles Darwin in 1871) and more contemporary theories that draw on evolutionary explanations, cultural variation, and evidence from actual mating behaviors.

## Common Preferences

Physical attractiveness is highly desired among men and women because it functions as a cue to fertility and health.(no content)Though men tend to prioritize and prefer physical attractiveness more so than women, it is still a quality that is highly desired by both sexes.(no content)Mate values that have continuously been seen as preferential include fertility, reproductive ability, health, age, intelligence, status, parenting skills, kindness, and willingness and ability to invest in offspring.

## Assortative Mating

Humans generally prefer mates who share the same or similar traits, such as genetics, quantitative phenotypes like height or body-mass index, skin pigmentation, the level of physical attractiveness, disease risk, race or ethnicity, facial features, socioeconomic factors, cultural backgrounds, moral values, religious beliefs, political orientation, personality traits, behavioral characteristics, educational attainment, and IQ or general intelligence.

Human mate preferences are shaped by a combination of evolutionary factors, cultural influences, and individual characteristics that vary across populations and contexts.

I've completed the web search for "cross-cultural comparison research." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Cross-cultural studies is a specialization in anthropology and sister sciences (sociology, psychology, economics, political science) that uses field data from many societies to examine the scope of human behavior and test hypotheses about human behavior and culture.

## Historical Development

The first cross-cultural studies were carried out by 19th-century anthropologists such as Edward Burnett Tylor and Lewis H. Morgan.(no content)The term "cross-cultural" emerged in the social sciences in the 1930s, largely as a result of the Cross-Cultural Survey undertaken by George Peter Murdock, a Yale anthropologist.

## Key Methodological Tools

The modern era of cross-cultural studies began with George Murdock (1949), who set up foundational data sets including the Human Relations Area Files and the Ethnographic Atlas, and together with Douglas R. White, developed the Standard Cross-Cultural Sample.

## Contemporary Research Areas

Links: [{"title":"Prevalence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prevalence"},{"title":"List of epidemics and pandemics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_epidemics_and_pandemics"},{"title":"Discovery of disease-causing pathogens - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discovery_of_disease-causing_pathogens"},{"title":"Pathogen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogen"},{"title":"Human pathogen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_pathogen"},{"title":"Pathogenic bacteria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogenic_bacteria"},{"title":"Sociality and disease transmission - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociality_and_disease_transmission"},{"title":"Pathogenesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogenesis"},{"title":"Epidemic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic"},{"title":"Spillover infection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spillover_infection"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about pathogen prevalence and disease:

## Definition of Prevalence

In epidemiology, prevalence is the proportion of a particular population found to be affected by a medical condition at a specific time, expressed as a fraction, percentage, or the number of cases per 10,000 or 100,000 people.(no content)Prevalence is the number of disease cases present in a particular population at a given time, whereas incidence is the number of new cases that develop during a specified time period.

## Types of Pathogens

The term pathogen typically describes an infectious microorganism or agent, such as a virus, bacterium, protozoan, prion, viroid, or fungus.(no content)Diseases in humans that are caused by infectious agents are known as pathogenic diseases.

## Factors Affecting Pathogen Prevalence

An increase in community size and density produces an increase of risk and prevalence of pathogenic infection. Additionally, epidemics of infectious disease are generally caused by several factors including a change in the ecology of the host population, a genetic change in the pathogen reservoir or the introduction of an emerging pathogen to a host population.

## Global Disease Burden

Infectious diseases with high prevalence are listed separately, such as malaria, which may have killed 50–60 million people.(no content)A GBD study estimated that bacterial pathogen infections contributed to one in 8 deaths (or ~7.7 million deaths), which could make it the second largest cause of death globally in 2019.

Web search results for query: "replication crisis psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Replication crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replication_crisis"},{"title":"Reproducibility Project - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproducibility_Project"},{"title":"Reproducibility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproducibility"},{"title":"Talk:Replication crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Replication_crisis"},{"title":"Social psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_psychology"},{"title":"Norbert Schwarz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norbert_Schwarz"},{"title":"OHBM Replication Award - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OHBM_Replication_Award"},{"title":"Replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replication"},{"title":"Pseudoreplication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudoreplication"},{"title":"Existential crisis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Existential_predicament"}]

Here are the search results for the replication crisis in psychology:

## Overview

The replication crisis, also known as the reproducibility or replicability crisis, refers to widespread failures to reproduce published scientific results.(no content)Psychology and medicine have been focal points for replication efforts, with researchers systematically reexamining classic studies to verify their reliability and, when failures emerge, to identify the underlying causes.

## Origins and Timeline

The phrase "replication crisis" was coined in the early 2010s as part of a growing awareness of the problem.(no content)Key precursors included social priming failures, with two direct replication attempts failing to reproduce results from social psychologist John Bargh's much-cited "elderly-walking" study (originally published in 1996).

## Key Findings

One major study found striking results: 97 of the original studies had significant effects, but of those 97, only 36% of the replications yielded significant findings (p value below 0.05), and the effects were often smaller than those in the original papers.

## Contributing Factors

Questionable research practices often involve converting undesired statistical outcomes into desired outcomes via the manipulation of statistical analyses, sample sizes, or data management systems, typically to convert non-significant findings into significant ones.(no content)Researchers focusing too much on novel discoveries instead of scrutinizing previously published findings was a big contribution to the reproducibility crisis in psychology.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "attractiveness physical appearance"

Links: [{"title":"Physical attractiveness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_attractiveness"},{"title":"Physical attractiveness stereotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_attractiveness_stereotype"},{"title":"Interpersonal attraction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpersonal_attraction"},{"title":"Lookism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appearance_discrimination"},{"title":"Human physical appearance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_physical_appearance"},{"title":"Category:Physical attractiveness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Physical_attractiveness"},{"title":"Averageness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Averageness"},{"title":"Facial symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_(physical_attractiveness)"},{"title":"Sexual attraction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_appeal"},{"title":"Beauty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beauty"}]

I've performed a web search on "attractiveness physical appearance." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Physical attractiveness is the extent to which a person's physical features are considered aesthetically pleasing or beautiful.(no content)The term often implies sexual attractiveness or desirability but can also be distinct from them.

## Factors Influencing Attractiveness

Physical attraction includes universal perceptions common across human cultures, such as facial symmetry, as well as socioculturally dependent attributes, and personal preferences unique to each individual.

Key specific factors include:
- **Facial Symmetry**: Facial symmetry has been found to increase ratings of attractiveness in human faces.
- **Averageness**: When images of human faces are averaged together to form a composite image, they become progressively closer to the "ideal" image and are perceived as more attractive.
- **Youth**: Younger women are more physically attractive – indeed in many ways beauty and youth are inextricable.

## Psychological Effects

In many cases, humans subconsciously attribute positive characteristics, such as intelligence and honesty, to physically attractive people, a psychological phenomenon called the halo effect.(no content)Overall, those who are physically attractive benefit from their good looks: physically attractive individuals are perceived more positively and physical attractiveness has a strong influence on judgement of a person's competence.

Web search results for query: "human mating behavior reproduction"

Links: [{"title":"Human mating strategies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_mating_strategies"},{"title":"Mating system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mating_system"},{"title":"Mating - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mating"},{"title":"Human sexual activity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_sexual_activity"},{"title":"Mate choice in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mate_choice_in_humans"},{"title":"Sexual strategies theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_strategies_theory"},{"title":"Assortative mating - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assortative_mating"},{"title":"Sexual selection in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_selection_in_humans"},{"title":"Animal sexual behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mating_of_animals"},{"title":"Strategic pluralism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_pluralism"}]

I've completed the web search for "human mating behavior reproduction." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Human mating strategies are a topic of interest in evolutionary psychology, behavioral ecology, and anthropology.(no content)Except in cases of arranged marriages, the human mating process involves one person meeting another to assess his or her suitability, courtship, and the formation an interpersonal relationship.

## Mating Strategies

Human mating strategies are a set of behaviors used by individuals to attract, select, and retain mates, and overlap with reproductive strategies that encompass behaviors involving the timing of reproduction and trade-offs between quantity and quality of offspring.(no content)Humans have evolved multiple mating strategies, and each strategy has specialised design features.

## Mating Systems

Compared to other vertebrates, where a species usually has a single mating system, humans display great variety and differ by having formal marriages, which in some cultures involve negotiation and arrangement between elder relatives.(no content)One estimate is that 83% of human societies are polygynous, 0.05% are polyandrous, and the rest are monogamous.

## Mate Selection

Although human males and females are both selective in deciding with whom to mate, females exhibit more mate choice selectivity than males.(no content)Body odor is another crucial criterion in assessing the suitability of a mate, and in humans, some olfactory receptors are directly connected to the parts of the brain controlling reproductive behavior.

## Motivation

The desire for companionship and sex drive are some of the strongest motivations of human behavior.

Human mating behavior is influenced by both evolutionary and cultural factors, making it particularly complex compared to other species.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Sex Differences in Mate Preferences Across 45 Countries: A Large-Scale Replication."

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Triples Extracted:** 11 entities across 4 types:
- **1 Task:** Mate choice in humans
- **7 Concepts:** Sex differences in psychology, Evolutionary psychology, Biosocial theory, Physical attractiveness, Gender equality, Prevalence, Human mating strategies
- **2 Methods:** Cross-cultural studies, Replication
- **1 Data:** Dataset (the new 45-country sample proposed by the paper)

**Key Findings:**
- The paper is classified as a **contribution** because it introduces a new large-scale 45-country dataset (N=14,399) for testing mate preference theories
- All triples have been mapped to their corresponding Wikipedia articles
- The paper **uses** established concepts and methodologies from evolutionary psychology, biosocial theory, and cross-cultural research methods
- The paper **proposes** a new dataset that enables replication and testing of classic mate preference studies with contemporary data
- Validation has passed with all requirements met

Sources:
- [Mating preferences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mating_preferences)
- [Sex differences in psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_differences_in_psychology)
- [Evolutionary psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology)
- [Biosocial theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biosocial_theory)
- [Physical attractiveness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_attractiveness)
- [Gender equality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_equality)
